title: FAB
summary: Floating action button persists across screens for constant access to features that needs to be accessible at all times.
preamble: The Floating action button (FAB) is a prominent button that provides quick access to a key action on the screen. It floats above the interface, making it easy to reach without disrupting the content layout. Use it to highlight actions that users are likely to take frequently or need quick access to.

overview.title: Usage
overview.section-content:
The FAB is a high-visibility button used to promote a **key action** on a screen. It typically floats above the content, anchored to a corner (usually bottom-right or bottom-center on mobile).

Use the FAB when a single, standout action is needed such as "Add", "Create", or "Start". It should never compete with other primary actions and should be used **sparingly** to avoid visual clutter.

overview.title: Variants
overview.section-content:
The FAB can be adapted based on layout and context:

*   **FAB** – A circular button with an icon (e.g. a plus sign for “Add”)
    
*   **Extended FAB** – A wider button with both an icon and a label (e.g. “Add item”). Useful when more clarity is needed.

dolist.text: Use the FAB for a single, primary action on the screen.
Choose a clear, meaningful icon that reflects the action.
Use extended FABs when users may need extra clarity about the action.
Ensure the FAB doesn’t obstruct important content, especially on smaller screens.
Keep FAB behavior consistent across views.

dontlist.text: Use multiple FABs on the same screen, it confuses the user and defeats its purpose.
Use FABs for secondary or low-priority actions.
Place the FAB where it might block content or keyboard input.
Use FABs for navigation—use links or tabs instead.
Forget to test FAB placement and visibility across screen sizes and modes (light/dark).
